Posts.Title: Helpful photos for young women considering no reconstruction Erica Jeanne44

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 07:20PM Hoolianama0508 wrote: I think that in order to maintain a sense of normalcy you have to be honest with your feelings. And by posting here you are doing exactly that. I was just diagnosed last week this time and like you, due to my medical history, I will have a double mastectomy and chemotherapy. Right away I plunged into despair and feared the worst. One day I heard my children laughing in their room and I broke down crying. I want to be here for my children and see them grow up. Suddenly, I felt that was being threatened. My daughter heard me and asked me why I was crying. I told her that I was frustrated about my boob. She looked at me and said, "don't be frustrated, don't worry, we're here."  This is when I realized that as scared as I am about the near future, my two kids are worth a million boobies. I am still afraid however I can face this by setting goals for myself.  My first goal is to connect with wonderful and strong women who have walked in my shoes and to support anyone that has just been diagnosed. My medical goal is to get a second opinion, which is scheduled for 4/8/09. Once I have that, I can proceed with faith in my doctors and their suggested treatment. My goal for the house is, "if it ain't dangerous, it can wait.' My goal for my children, to have more patience. The rest is still a work in progress.  I pray you find your answers and wish you the very best.
Posts.Title: 31 and just diagnosed amiekae Jodi_Smart

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2010 08:18PM Hoolianama0508 wrote: I had the 4 nuclear injections for my bilateral mastectomy and it did not hurt as bad as I imagined it would. The technician was super in explaining how everything worked which helped to relax me a little bit. I spent the night before sugery in tears worrying about the injections. In retrospect, the nuclear dye itself was the culprit since it burns as it goes in.
Posts.Title: Nuclear Injection pre-surgery pagowens Accepted2018

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2009 01:11AM Hoolianama0508 wrote: I agree beastybabe, it is helpful to know how your loved ones are truly feeling, because it allows you to do the same and not put on a brave front when you are terrified. The best approach to offer of help that springs to my mind was when a friend said, "What can I do to help?" It was a relief to hear that instead of "I'm so sorry." My mum and I are close and I know she is upset and worried. She is helping me by watching my children while my husband and I go to doctor's appointments. If you live close by her, offer to go with her to appointments. It is actually better to have another person with you since a person can feel overwhelmed with all the medical terms. My cousin did that for me at my second opinion visit. I asked to to take notes and ask questions if she saw I was not responding or falling into silence. She was great. This place is a wealth of information, comfort and support. We will do all we can to help you both through this. Hugs to you and your mum.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 03:48PM Hoolianama0508 wrote: Jojo, If you cannot see the 2nd opinion doctor for 3 1/2 weeks, ask her to refer you to someone else who can see you sooner. Even if it means driving a long distance, it is better than worrying for 3 1/2 weeks. This is not good for your mind, body, and spirit. When I was diagnosed in Orlando, Florida in 2009 with stage 3 bc, I immediately got a 2nd opinion in North Carolina. Although the suggested treatment was the same, I at least felt a sense of relief that I would be getting the correct treatment at my local cancer hospital. I opted for a bilateral mastectomy once I knew what my options were and "weren't."  It is important to make the very best, informed decision you can make once you have all the facts. These messages boards have been my lifeline before, during and after my treatments. I hope this can be helpful.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 11:36PM Hoolianama0508 wrote: aaronali12 The early days of diagnosis, in my opinion, is the scariest of times because our normal life is turned upside down. I want to encourage you to continue to ask questions of your doctor, this message board and even think of getting a second opinion. It is hard to absorb, let alone accept, the diagnosis within a few days or weeks. This is my 4th week after being diagnosed and I still have questions that I will find answers to. I too am concerned that they want to do aggressive treatments on a grade 1 tumor, however, I am not a physician. Utilize as many resources as you can to help keep yourself informed of treatments and options. I have 3 tumors in my left breast, 1 of them is at least 5cm. My oncologist and surgeon both suggest chemo first to shrink the largest tumor down and then surgery to remove the breast. There tumors are too far apart to save the breast in my case. I pray you will find the best treatment plan for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2010 09:14PM Hoolianama0508 wrote: Carol, I don't know how to begin to comfort you, so I hope what I say will be supportive. My first reaction is that you need to get as far away from this man because he is toxic and this impedes your healing. You need to be surrounded by positive people and not negative ones. Now let me step back from that statement. I understand that financially, you need him around to share the burden. Besides the finances, what is the other reason you need him in your life? If it is love, then I say that his love is also toxic. I don't know how it got to this point, however, I can only say that you DO NOT deserve this treatment. You are facing this challenge and living as strong as you can. You are working AND doing treatments?!  That is major. Now speaking of the "friend". Basically the issue is not her, it is really his disdain for you. The other woman is an excuse. Even if she disappeared tomorrow, it is his treatment of you that needs to be changed. Saying that God is punishing you for being bad is absolutely ludacris. Our God is a loving God and do not let him use that to keep you down. There are so many resources out there for women facing breast cancer. You stated that you are stage 4 and you have had other medical conditions that you faced recently.  I am sure there is a mountain of assistance for you just because of your stage. I want you to know that you are valuable, you are worthy. You matter. You count. You are important. Never mind this illness/dis-ease; you are still worthy of respect. Let your doctor know what you are facing. Most hospitals have social workers that can put you in touch with resources. Believe it or not, verbal abuse is taken very seriously as domestic violence. At the end of the day, the choice is yours. You decide how happy or sad your life will be. Your life is not over. Keeping you in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: Spouse that just doesn't care my3sonz cancersuks

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 04:13PM Hoolianama0508 wrote: naomib04, Sorry you are on this journey but we are here to help you. Many questions jump to mind when you are first diagnosed. The doctors should be able to tell you the following before any treatment begins: 1) what type of cancer is this 2) how big is the tumor(s) 3) are any lymph nodes involved 4) has it travelled to the bones or other organs These are standard questions the doctors should answer once they have all the info back from the biopsy. Question 4 should be answered once they do a bone scan. Chemotherapy is the standard treatment first because they need to see if the tumor is reponding to it. If it is at all possible, get a second opinion from another facility that has a breast cancer program, just to make sure the standard of care is correct. I am praying everything goes well for you. This is an excellent place for support.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer at 26 naomib04 naomib04

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 11:13AM Hoolianama0508 wrote: Hi there Stratton, First, I want to send you a big hug as I know this journey is "no pleasure cruise" for anyone. (quoting from Queen) From what I gathered on the internet about PET scans, it helps identify problem areas in the body by using a tracer.  I looked at the following website since I am having this done soon before chemo; http://www.petscaninfo.com/zportal/portals/pat/faq I think it would be a good idea to have the PET scan prior to chemo and surgery, if possible. In my opinion, I think physicians should see the big picture before they inject or surgically remove any part of our bodies. What province do you live in? I am currently residing in Florida, however I lived in Ontario for a few years. I'd be happy to assist you in researching any information you need.
